messages: f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (21:53): it would be nice if we just developed a nice web based tool which could take an SVG image, strip out all the namespaced stuff that would be non-conforming in HTML and send back the image to the user ready to copy and paste into their HTML
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (21:53): though, maybe it would have to replace the creative commons stuff with a simpler, conforming alternative that means the same thing
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:17): Should be easy if you have an XML dom, right?
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (22:22): should be fairly easy to make as a Python app
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (22:22): (I say that because I know a bit of Python)

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (22:35): yeah, and as long as the input is well formed XML, then it shouldn't be too hard. But if we want to handle some non-well-formed input, or input with namespace errors, and be able to output valid SVG for text/html, it would be harder
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (22:37): btw, that Wikipedia logo in text/html page that Shelley made really makes Firefox slow to use
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (22:38): you could use my XML5 code
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (22:38): but euh, I thought the point was copy and pasting well-formed XML
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (22:40): you could probably also just use html5lib and filter out the implied <html>, <head>, <body> crap
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (22:40): yeah, but we know authors don't always make XML based SVG well formed
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (22:40): we also know that content doesn't work

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (22:42): using html5lib would put all the namespaced stuff like <dc:foo> and prefixed attributes into the wrong namespace, so filtering wouldn't be as simple as stripping out anything that isn't in the SVG, MathML or HTML namespace, nor an atribute in no namespace

4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (22:42): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c, I was wondering if http://developer.apple.com/safari/library/documentation/iPhone/Conceptual/SafariJSDatabaseGuide/OfflineApplicationCache/OfflineApplicationCache.html is correct for WebKit as it seems like it contradicts HTML5 for fallback entries
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (22:42): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c, I asked in #webkit earlier but nobody was around that could help
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (22:43): 4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b: that documentation could be out of date, but it's also possible the implementation is out of date with the spec
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (22:43): 4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b: what's the specific point of contradiction?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (22:44): 4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b: andersca is the person most likely to know offhand, for me to know the exact current behavior I would need to test

4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (22:45): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c, it suggests that for a fallback thingy of /foo/ /bar/ a failed load of /foo/1.htm loads /bar/1.htm where as HTML5 suggests it should load /bar/
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (22:47): I haven't tested myself. Did find that the Firefox documentation does support my interpretation of HTML5...
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (22:47): 4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b: I'm not sure if it actually does that, but if so it's probably unintentional, or an error of interpretation
4d647473081c3ad729446a01a377813b (22:48): kk, I pinged andersca just in case

0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (22:49): changes topic to 'WHATWG (HTML5) -- http://www.whatwg.org/ -- Logs: http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/ -- Vennligst legg igjen din logiske sans ved d??ren, takk!'
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (22:52): Leave your sense of logic at the door in... Norwegian?
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (23:01): the original seems to have been auto-translated initially
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (23:01): 0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17, yeah, google translate helped me a little bit with a few words in the original
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (23:01): it's now valid Norwegian, but a bit strained, and we would never say "thank you"
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (23:02): 0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17, that's just because norwegians are impolite :-)
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (23:02): it's just that ", takk" in Norwegian implies that you expect compliance
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (23:02): so instead of being a polite request, it's now a fairly rude way of ordering people around
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (23:03): changes topic to 'WHATWG (HTML5) -- http://www.whatwg.org/ -- Logs: http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/ -- V?¶r vennlig og legg igjen din logiske sans i d??ren'
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (23:03): then let's change it back to the english version, which doesn't suffer from that problem
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (23:03): Now it, pretty directly is "Be polite and leave your sense of logic at the door"
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (23:04): s/directly/literally/
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (23:04): but the implied translation changes "v?¶r vennlig" to "please"
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (23:04): Google translate says otherwise: "Please leave your logical sense at the door". But I suppose I can trust your translation a little more
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (23:04): please, though, directly would translate to "be kind"
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (23:04): or "be so kind"
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (23:05): ah, like vars?•god in Swedish
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (23:05): I thought vennligst meant please
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (23:05): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: depends on whether you want to order people around or be polite
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (23:06): oh, so those signs I've seen around that say things like "Vennligst vent her" are ordering me around, instead of making a polite request?
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (23:11): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: the differences are subtle, though
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (23:11): it's not like in dutch airports
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (23:11): where their last call messages are saying "[Insert name], proceed to gate immediately, you are delaying the flight"
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (23:15): I wish IRC were more resillient to this kind of server adjustments, without causing so many splits
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:21): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220, every other chat protocol seems not to have this problem . . .
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (23:22): IRC is *old* though

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (23:22): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762, it's not really surprising. IRC is one of the oldest chat protocols still in common use. Newer protocols probably learned from its shortcomings
